description.text:
Check out mekmekmek's customizable version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:188285 Hutch914 put it in the Makerbot customizer, too, if that's your thing.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1096880 Rather than spend time printing springs for a project, I made this little mold to make them out of raw 3mm PLA filament. It measures 3/4" by 3" tall. Since there are no shear planes in this twisted filament, the springs it creates will be a lot tougher than anything printed. I think this concept could be used to produce torsion springs as well as conical compression springs with different molds. If you wrapped the filament around a dowel with the sides of the filament touching, you could make an extension spring instead of a compression spring.

Please see the JPG in the gallery here:
http://thingiverse-production.s3.amazonaws.com/assets/7d/20/21/46/67/spring_instructions.jpg Autodesk Inventor file is included for modification.

comments.text: Have you tested it to see if it follows Hooke's Law and if you can get a predictable spring constant?
comments.author: MishaT

comments.text: You will get a predictable spring constant for most materials as long as they stay in the elastic region, as soon as you get plastic deformation (deformation that will not return back to it's original size and shape) it will no longer conform to Hooke's law past that stress point.

comments.text: As Makulator also said, these springs will loose their tension over time. So they may only be useful for limited applications. They look nice though.
comments.author: Psych0o

comments.text: By time, too. Thermoplastic materials exhibit time-dependent strain when exposed to constant load, and constant load inflicts time-dependent tension. They partly behave like fluids, and a unloaded spring will not relax completely to the size it was before loading. The remaining deformation depend on time and force applied. So the force of a compressed spring will diminish over time.

This thing is a set of tools to help adapt a makerbot or other 3-axis CNC machine into a gigapixel imageBot. This is an extension of the Explorable Microscopy project. http://www.explorablemicroscopy.org/ Some example images:
720 megapixel Arduino http://gigapan.org/gigapans/77742/
200 megapixel Crab shell http://gigapan.org/gigapans/78874/
60 megapixel fly http://gigapan.org/gigapans/79492/ The goal is to make the generation of very very large, explorable images, as simple as possible, bringing this technique to more people. An important aspect of this goal is to make as few modifications to the equipment as possible. The idea here is to capture thousands of images of a single subject in a 3D array, then merge these images into a single explorable image which can be viewed online using the free gigapixel image sharing site, http://www.gigapan.org . The process is broken up into four steps: â€¢ Image capture - automatic capture of thousands of images in a 3D array.
â€¢ Focus stacking - merging images of different focus into a single all in focus image.
â€¢ Image stitching - merging adjacent images in an xy plane into a single large image.
â€¢ Upload/sharing - uploading to the gigapan website for sharing and exploring. This thing specifically addresses the first of these four steps, image capture. A video of the thing in progress can be found here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jKSs6J-xn18 This thing was greatly influenced by Rich Gibson who had the initial impetus to work on it, so much so, that he bought a makerbot that he then let me play with.

Setup your imageBot: 1) Mount a camera to you CNC machine.
Obviously for small working spaces a camera with appropriate magnification for the subject is important. I'm using a DSLR, canon T2i with the stock lens and a ~$10 reversing ring to gain magnification. A proper macro lens may work better but for ~$10 I'm getting great results. Newer point and shots may be able to achieve a reasonable level of magnification in macro mode for many subjects. Unfortunately I haven't made a general purpose camera mount. Mine was made from a bit of t-slot extrusion and a few screws, the camera mount screw is 1/4" by 20 thread count. Each camera will be a little different so be creative. 2) Make and connect electronic trigger.
On DSLRs this can be done through the electronic shutter, an example of how to wire the shutter for some DSLRs can be found here (http://martybugs.net/blog/blog.cgi/gear/CanonN3Connector.html). I simply short the inner most and outer most pins on the stereo plug using a relay. For a cheaper solution one can use CHDK enabled Canon point and shoot cameras and trigger them via the USB, check here (http://chdk.wikia.com/wiki/USB_Remote_Cable) for directions. The electronic trigger then needs to be connected to your hardware. In the case of the makerbot I've got it triggering through the fan port on the extruder board. The python code that generates the G-code for image capture inserts the take picture command, which in this case is fan on/fan off, M106/M107, although these can be changed via the command line options. 3) Add lights.
Pretty straightforward, good pictures require good lighting. Be creative. I wired up a couple of high power LEDs to the makerbot power supply. Taking pictures: 1) Determine the field-of-view and depth-of-field.
In order to figure out how many images you need to take to cover a subject you must first determine the field-of-view and depth-of-field of the lens you're using. The field of view is easy, either place a ruler under the camera and count, or using the manual controls, advance the stage in the x direction until an object passes from one side of the image to the limit of the other side. The depth-of-field is a little more tricky to determine precisely. You can estimate it by again using the control panel in replicatorG to advance the z stage, seeing a plane comes into focus and when it falls out of focus. A slightly more rigorous method is to measure it directly using a ruler at 45 degrees, the measured width in focus should then be equal to the depth. 2) Generate your array using grid.py
For all the details on using grid.py type "./gird.py --help". You must first determine the bound of your subject, this is easily done by using the replicatorG control panel to jog in x,y, and z. Set home to the bottom, lower, left corner and work your way to the top, upper, right corner (all units should be positive). Once found these values are used to generate the array, a typical example is: ./grid.py --x=40 --y=13 --z=3 --depth-of-field=0.15 --z-overlap=0 --picture-delay=1500 > crab03.gcode This sets our x to 40mm wide, y to 13mm high, and z to 3mm deep. The depth of field for this lens was found to be around ~0.15mm. There is no z-overlap, the picture delay is 2*1.5 seconds and the output is being saved to crab03.gcode. 3) Start image capture.
Home your bot to the 0,0,0 you chose when defining the subject space. Open the gcode produced by grid.py and hit "buld". Post image capture, stacking, stitching and uploading: 1) To aid in image processing it's convenient to group each focus stack into a single folder. The python code zsort.py can help with this. zsort.py sorts sequentially shot and numbered images into subdirectories for batch focus stacking. Usage: ./zsort.py PREFIX n1 n2 n3 where PREFIX is the image name prefix like "IMG" for canon cameras, n1 is the number of images per stack, n2 is the total number of images and n3 is the trim factor. Call zsort from the folder containing the image set to be sorted. If the trim factor is zero it will copy all the images for each stack. If it's some integer larger than zero it will select the top n3 largest images and copy them over. This is a dirty way of speeding up the focus stacking for compressed images, where the file size directly relates to the amount of "information" in the image. Larger images tend to be more in focus than smaller ones. This only works well for relatively flat subjects. 2) Focus stacking.
There a a few focus stacking software packages available, including some free and open source versions, particularly those written for imageJ. For these test however, I've used Zerene stacker (http://www.zerenesystems.com/) because of it's good quality and ease in batch processing. 3) Image stitching.
Again, there are many options for image mosaic stitching including free versions such as ptGui, although due to it's ease, I'm using the gigapan stitcher. 4) Uploading.
gigapan.org offers a completely free service for uploading, viewing, sharing, and annotating gigapixel scale images. The only requirement is that the minimum image size exceed 50 megapixels :)

Bassoonists typically use a crutch to keep their right hand in the correct posture. However, this part's dimensions depend on the user's hand size, and as a result, players with small hands (typically younger students) are unable to use a crutch and develop poor hand posture. This part costs about $20-$30 to purchase and can cost more if a professional wants a custom designed crutch. This design aims to allow those with 3d printers to create custom crutches and print them out for less than 50 cents worth of filament. This design has a stem that's only 19 mm long, as opposed to the standard 24 mm length, and the palm of the hand sits only 13 mm from the crutch holder, instead of the typical 20 mm.

I printed it as shown in the design with supports, 100% infill and PLA plastic. I needed to sand down the part (both the rod to reduce the diameter, and the part itself for smoothness). It was strong enough if printed in this orientation.

title: Roomba upgraded CHM support bearing (and carpet upgrade)

description.text:
The iRobot Roomba (500 series) is a good robot, and a helpful roommate, but suffers from a weak transmission. On many Roombas, the gearbox fails because dirt, fur, PLA strands, and other debris enters the gearbox and increases resistance. This is a repair/upgrade which addresses one of the primary failure modes of the CHM/cleaning head/gearbox.

The primary failure mode is that due to the ingress of debris, this resistance gets progressively worse until the subsequent heat eventually causes the plastic housing to deform and fail, presenting either as a brush box error or a failure to rotate the main cleaning brushes. This appears to happen primarily at the two output wheels (where debris enters) and the first driven gear, (where the rotational speed is highest). This is a bearing shim which fits into the CHM deck and prevents the metal gear axle from moving into the empty space beyond the CHM chassis. This part is designed to fit precisely into the space behind the CHM, and will align with the edge of the chassis.
It is designed with a radial cutout which will allow sufficient range of motion for the gearbox/brush motor to effectively adjust its height, but it will prevent the motor tab from touching the support lug at the bottom of the CHM, which allows proper fitment, and reduces wear on the height adjustment wheel and bushing.
This part was designed based on the green CHM module, but it may fit other CHM modules (black and red). If your CHM has not yet failed, this part will prevent it from failing. As iRobot has replaced the older CHM modules, the only other repair strategy is to replace the CHM with the new grey CHM (~$50).

This bearing support was designed in sketchup, and is designed to be printed at 100%. There are zero thickness walls present to improve strength at some junctions, and an overhang which must be printed cleanly to function properly. I recommend printing with supports if your printer isn't great at bridging. The Carpet version will modify the deck clearance to be increased and prevent excess motor load if Roomba is always on carpeted surfaces. The carpet upgrade increases Roomba's minimum brush clearance, and is designed to improve performance on carpeted and uneven surfaces. It may reduce Roomba's bare-floor performance, but may also resolve brush box errors (and should only be used after a thorough cleaning of the gearbox). It is to be considered a prototype upgrade, rather than a fully optimized design.

This part should press into place and remain there, but can be strengthened by a drop of glue at the edge between the CHM and the support if your print is not accurately calibrated. It is also retained by the blue support chassis which surrounds the CHM, and should not be lost if it becomes loose.
It could be improved by the addition of a hard bearing point (such as metal or glass) beneath the cap, but should be sufficient to resolve the problem in most cases.

A student designed paperclip or pencil cup made for teacher appreciation week.

Students worked with a partner to design a pencil/paper clip holder for Teacher Appreciation week. This was our first project with 3D design and printing. It's a great project for any beginner.

Show students how to drag simple geometric shapes on to the design plane. Then, show them how to use simple tools to hollow the solid shapes, bevel edges, and attach pieces (letters, base plate) to the shape.

This project motivates and engages students. They have plenty of options for customizing and personalizing projects with varying degrees of difficulty. As a result, everyone can create something. Students also take a lot of pride in seeing their projects used by their teachers.

  • Raspberry Pi 3 (UPDATED 9/10/16)
  • Raspberry Pi 2
  • Raspberry Pi Model B+

Details
This Raspberry Pi case inspired by my old Raspberry Pi Model B case. Like my other design this new Pi case features:

  • Access slot for Pi camera
  • Screw together design
  • Screw mounting of Raspberry Pi to case using holes in PCB
  • Built in 75mm VESA mounting tabs
  • Rotary engine (reuleaux triangle) vent design
  • High resolution STL mesh

Also, as always, STEP files of the two halves of the case are attached as well for those who would like to tweak the design for their own use.

If anyone finds any problems (dimensionally or otherwise) post them up so I can get the model fixed.

Change Log
3/1/18

  • To celebrate the success of this design (over half a million views and 169k downloads as of this writing), it is now on the standard Creative Commons - Attribution - Share Alike license. Thanks to everyone who has printed this and shared their comments and pictures!

10/29/16

  • Uploaded Raspberry Pi 3 standard bottom STEP file.

9/10/16

  • Added new models for Raspberry Pi 3 (both standard and 100mm VESA versions) that will allow for easier removal of SD card.

10/8/15

  • Added base design for mounting directly to 8020 extrusions with M5 hardware.
  • Updated STL's for 25mm and 30mm fan mount tops

9/8/15

  • Added top cover design for mounting a 25mm fan.
  • Added top cover design for mounting a 30mm fan.

7/25/15

  • Added base design with 75mm/100mm VESA mounting holes.

Instructions
For Raspberry Pi Model B+ and Raspberry Pi 2

  • Pick one file labeled "rpi2-bottom" and one labeled "rpi2-top"

For Raspberry Pi 3

  • Pick one file labeled "rpi3-bottom" and one labeled "rpi2-top". Alternatively you can use any "rpi2-bottom" as well, but access to remove the SD card will be more restrictive.

Hardware

  • Raspberry Pi to bottom: Four #4 x 1/4" sheet metal screws (Alternative: M3 x 6mm)
  • Top to bottom: Four #4 x 3/4" sheet metal screws (Alternative: M3 x 18mm)

comments.text: I had a similar problem.  Cura wouldn't do any infill so it would just leave it out.  I changed from 3 perimeters to 2 and also changed infill to 100%. I then stepped through the layers to verify it was going to fill everything in.  Sorry I don't know MatterControl.

comments.text: What extrusion width are you using? It works best with 0.5mm
comments.author: christiangentry

comments.text: I have an e3d with the .4
comments.author: 0110-M-P

comments.text: I also run an E3D with 0.4mm nozzle. Typically you want your extrusion width to be at least 10% larger than your nozzle diameter (so minimum extrusion width of 0.44mm). I run my extrusion width at 0.5mm because it makes designing components easier for perfect wall thicknesses. Your 0.4mm nozzle will have no problem with a 0.5mm extrusion width.
comments.author: christiangentry

comments.text: So, how exactly is that possible?
comments.author: 0110-M-P

comments.text: It looks like a separate extrusion width setting is missing from MatterControl settings. This is odd considering every other slicer I have used (Simplify3D, KISSlicer, Slic3r,  Curaetc) have this setting separate from nozzle diameter. I like a lot of things about MatterControl, but its limitations for adjustment like this always kept me going back to KISS and S3D.

Thank you. I printed your box with PLA and it worked fine. For larger ABS boxes I've found I've also had to add a 1.6% shrink rule to dimensions. A PC board with a hole spacing of say 3.25" ends up with the holes spaced 3.198" apart so I have to draw them 3.3" apart so the PC board holes line up with the printed holes.
I use Repetier for Slicing. Do you know of a way to increase the solid plastic around the hole area while maintaining 20% infill for other areas. That's so if I did print the hole as a pilot hole and wanted to use the correct drill and tap I'd not run into the infill.

comments.text: This is very difficult to do. Some software (Simplify3D for example) can allow you to do different setting for different layers, but I don't know of any that could do different settings for different features on the same layer. The only way I know to do this is to have two models of each feature and print them on top of each other.

comments.text:
Hello, I have one more question.
Why did you optimize this design for an extrusion width of 0.5mm? I mean why 0.5mm, since almost every consumer-grade 3D printer (like Ultimaker, Zortrax, UP etc.) use 0.4mm nozzle. Wouldn't making every distance multiple of 0.4mm provide better quality? BTW, I've printed the bottom part of this case, it fits perfectly and looks beautiful, thanks! :) I will print the other half today.
And sorry for posting this 3 times, it's all this comment actually. Thingiverse just doesn't sort replies correctly so I ended up posting another comment
comments.author: muhsinfatih

comments.text:
Thanks.
It is generally accepted that you should print with extrusion widths greater than your nozzle diameter. The "go-to" default extrusion width of most slicers is 120% of the nozzle diameter. With a 0.4mm nozzle (what I use as well out of my E3D hot end) that would be 0.48mm.
The reason I choose 0.5mm is because it is much easier to design parts with features that are a multiple of that than pretty much anything else.
comments.author: muhsinfatih

This is a duct to use a 5v 5015s centrifugal fan (from ebay or amazon) blowing through the hole above the extruder stepper motor. The duct just clips into place and need no extra attachments, the air passes over the extruder, past the hot end heat sink and through the existing curved duct down to the hot end, creating a layer fan (of sorts!)

I got the fan from ebay, its a 5v 5015s centrifugal fan and costs 99p (in the UK!)

The photos show an early version printed without the fan, which I used to print the second version... with much improvement!

I use this in conjunction with the extruder fan shroud http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:856155 which means that all the air goes down the duct behind the hot end. You get quite a breeze under there now!

Wire the fan in parallel to the extruder fan (5v) so it is on when that fan is on. If you install repetier then you can repurpose this to be a layer fan. Just don't turn them all off or your filament will melt in the feed and block everything!

There are circumstances where you don't need a layer fan, either unplug it or turn it down in repetier, just don't turn them all off. So far I just leave them all on and up the extruder temperature by 5 deg.

I have found that the existing extruder fan runs a lot quieter, this will be because it's not pushing air through as efficiently, no doubt I will need to replace it with a centrifugal fan as well, once I work out how to get it to fit and not foul on everything when in the home position!

Print it upright with plenty of support. You need a layer fan to get the top to print without drooping!

I print at 6000mm/min with 20% infill and 35% speed reduction for layers < 5 seconds (so the top prints at around 600mm/min or 10mm/sec)

title: Prusa i3 Updated X-Axis Motor and Idler Ends

description.text:
I wanted to update my Prusa i3 Hepestos's X Ends and I also like the way that the X Ends from the Infill 3D i3Redux look.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:371842
https://infill3d.com/home/37-x-motor-mk52.html
https://infill3d.com/home/36-x-idler-mk41.html

So I combined the current functionality of the Hephestos with the looks of Infill 3D.

Features:
1) Belt Tensioner.
2) Anti-backlash on the Z-Axis.
3) Opto sensor mount for X-Axis home sensor.
4) Secure clamping of the X-Axis slide bars.

I incorporated a belt tensioner similar to the Hephestos design.

I'm using Opto sensors on my printer and did not like the stuck on look of the sensors so I added a mounting point for the X-Axis home sensor to the motor end

Anti-backlash is build into both X-Ends.

I added clamps on the X-Axis slide bars to lock them in place so the tensioning the belt would not distort the Y-Axis by pulling the X Ends closer to each other.

I will still create new cable chain mounts for the motor end.

As always, drop me some comments if you find errors or have improvements in mind.

Update 2015-07-13:
Uploaded source files in step format exported from TurboCAD. Unable to test the step files integrity as I can only take them back into TC.

Update 2015-07-24:
Added a slot on the motor end to reach the pulley grub screws

NB: The X Ends must be printed upright, same orientation as they are installed on the printer to get the best layer strength around the Z bearings. If you print them flat on their backs the there is a chance that the bearing holders will split when inserting the z bearings!!!

The belt tensioner is assembled with at least a 50mm long M4 Hexagon bolt and M4 nut. There is space for a 23mmx8mm coil spring over the M4 bolt between the tensioner and the X Idler End body.

Insert the nut into the back of the Tensioner Knob, you might need to warm the nut with a soldering iron(or similar) before fitting it. Next insert the bolt from the front into the Tensioner. Add the spring(if you want to). Insert the tensioner into the X Idler End body and push the M4 bolt through the hole at he back. Screw the tensioner knob onto the M4 bolt. Do not tighten it yet.

Next install the Idler bearings.

The belt tensioner uses 2 5x10x5 bearings as they are nearly the same diameter as my 16 tooth GT2-2mm pulley. A M3 x 18mm Allen Dome head with a M3 nut is used to fix the bearings. A 5mm OD by 3mm ID by 10mm long spacer must be inserted into the two bearings before mounting. There is some free space provided for the bearings to turn in.

Install the Opto sensor onto the motor end as shown on the "X Motor End with Opto Fitted.stl" file.
Assemble the rest of the motor end as normal.

Add 2 M5 nuts to the X ends from below. Add 2 suitable springs and then 2 M5 nuts from above. Put some pretension on the upper nuts as you thread the Z-Axis drive through them. You don't need much pre-tension, the drive rods should still turn easily

Now you can mount the new X Ends as normal on the 8mm slide bars (remember the carriage) and fit the X-Axis assemble onto the Z-Axis.

Tighten the 4 clamps with 4 M3x12mm(or 16mm) Allen Cap screws with 4 M3 nuts.

This is a project I'm still working on - it's a miniature bee hive. It's based on the classic Langstroth design. My goal is to make something that can printed on a 250mm x 200mm build platform such as my MakerGear M2.

So far I've modeled the brood box and one of the screens. I think this brood box design can also be used as a super. The screens need to be printed at 15% infill, hexagonal fill to achieve the 5mm cell size needed. The screen will need to be dipped in beeswax prior to use. I made it so 10 screens will fit in the box.
I'll be uploading a queen excluder, the baseboard and a roof soon.

Will it actually work? I have no idea, but the plans are to get with a beekeeper to improve the design as needed.

A simple zip tie style fan shroud for Hexagon AO's. I could not find any so I decided to make one for a sE1X.

7/20/15 -- UPDATE: Made a 2nd version after struggling to print PLA with the original version. This new one wraps around the entire fin section of the AO hotend and has 3 directional cuts in the back to direct airflow..if this does not work then v3 will have a spot to mount a 25mm fan to help pull out heat.

Dont forget to check out Mobious Robotics sometime, thanks! -pb

title: Super Simple Emax NightHawk Angled Camera Mount (15 degrees and 20 degrees)

description.text:
Simple angled mount for use with the stock anti-jello plate on top of the NightHawk 250. Use for Mobius, Runcam, or whatever type of camera fits on that plate. The mount can be held to the top plate by screws or zip ties.

Included are two different orientations for the 15 and 20 degree versions. One will need supports, but is stronger in my opinion (more consistent strength throughout the layers). The second is a faster print on its side (may be weaker at the jello mount point).

The good thing is these are fast to print so make extra in case that hard crash sneaks up on you.
I used 0.2mm layer thickness and 40% infill. There are not many infill layers at that height - so if you are needing to shave minuscule amounts of weight off your build, lower the percentage.

description.text:
My Girlfriend was crafting a fleece poncho made out of a custom Baymax print. When finished, she mused that she wished she had a Baymax head shaped button to use as a toggle clasp for it to attach with at the neck. Naturally I felt the need to whip something up for her!

This little guy is 5cm long, 2.5cm wide, and 6mm deep. The groove between his eyes is 2mm deep below the main surface to allow room for a threading to loop between the eye holes and into the cloth below. It could be used as a typical button if you have wide enough button holes, but in practice was design to be a toggle clasp paired with a textile loop. I also suggest filling in the groove and eye holes with black paint so that combined with the black thread the eyes have the perfect effect!

He can also be stitched onto any backing via the eye holes for other handy uses as well!

He prints best with a thick upper surface (I did 4 layers) and a 25% infill. (He needs to be durable but not overdone.) I printed him at 0.2mm as 1 seemed overkill as he has no surface curves and gentle rounding.
Wheel with radial holes for bolts and nuts that lock on shaft.
keytag

It's the first enemy you encounter in Bubble Bobble! Printed upside down, with the side thingy printed on the side, for all of your non-support needs! The side thingy should fit right into the hole on the side.

Have fun!

title: Single Use Model Rocket -- Mark II

description.text: This is an updated remix of the Single Use Model Rocket (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:87495 ). This version has a longer, solid nose to shift the center of gravity forward, and slightly longer fins, to pull the center of pressure backwards. Prints as a single intact object.

Printed with
Infill 100% (important! to maximize weight in nose)
Speed: 40mm/s
Shells: 3
Layer Height: 0.27 Print time = 1:49
Weight (empty) = 23g
Weight (w/ engine) = 48g With the center of gravity (CG) moved forward, this version should have better aerodynamics than version 1. This is designed to house an Estes 'C' standard sized model rocket engine.
See ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:88520 ) to adapt to an 'A' sized mini engine.

This is a coin mechanism I designed for a MAME arcade machine, LED Infra-red light bounces off the coins triggering a credit.
I didn't want to charge people money but liked the tactile experience of putting coins in.
This will accept any denomination (even washers or tokens I suppose) so I use a bunch of foreign coins I collected as a child.

The coin runs down the chute past an IR LED and a photo diode light sensor. When the IR light bounces off the coin going past it activates the diode triggering a key press. The circuit is quite simple and should work on any I-PAC or equivalent (I use a cut up USB game controller). This is a very simple circuit, only 2 components! The modules can be daisy chained and only need 4 wires for the first module then one extra wire per module.

I've included a cover plate but you could make your own out of metal for a more durable result

Suits any coins up to 35mm Dia x 4mm thick. Designed for an 18mm panel.

I screwed a small coin box under these mechanisms in my cabinet to catch the coins. Just cut two matching slots, see image.

Parts
2 x RPR-220 light sensor
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/RPR220-Optoelectronic-Switch-Reflective-Optical-Coupling-Sensor-10PCS-Lot/32214671867.html
2 x 27 Ohm resistor
2 x 20mm square prototype board
10 x Male header pins (or solder wires directly to board)

Print the two parts then glue together with Acetone or glue.

Your I-PAC or USB button interface should have a common 5V pin. All the buttons should connect to this. Connect the common 5V to both the RPR-220 collectors. Connect the inputs that you want to use as credit to the emitters of the RPR-220. When the RPR-220 receives light reflected from a passing coin the transistor will let 5V through to the I-PAC input triggering a button press and adding a credit.

Cut a bit of prototype board to size. 20x20mm
Solder on components as shown.

Pin 1 - 5V from PSU or USB
Pin 2 - 5V Ground
Pin 3 - Coin 1 Ground
Pin 4 - Coin 2 Ground
Pin 5 - Common positive feed from I-PAC
The second sensor board daisy chains to the other board sharing all the pins except for the coin 2 ground pin.

Slot one end of the board into the coin mechanism,
Put some hot glue on the post.
Position the board so that both the circles on the light sensor can be seen through the cut-out.
Press down into hot glue.

Use the template provided to drill pilot holes for the coin mech.
Drill two 10mm holes then cut between them to make a slot.
Fix the mechanisms to the inside of your arcade cabinet.

description.text:
This is a work derived from curiosity. I just wanted to know how it would be to juggle a printed devil stick. For those how do not yet know it, a devil stick is one of the lesser known objects for juggling, not as common as balls, clubs or diabolos. It is juggled by controlling it with two control sticks, that you hold in your hands.
The great advantage of a printed stick over a normal stick made of wood is that it can be disassembled, if you need to stow it away for travel. 
The result of my juggling experiment: it is a bit heavy for my taste (250g) but juggles allright. I can perform all the tricks I normally do with it as well. And it doesn't need tape because of its fine surface structure.

You will need to print one piece for the middle, two for the ends and two clamps. Additionally you will need a couple of M4 headless screws and a long thin staff made of wood (diameter 8mm).
Printing takes ages if you use fine layers (approx. 8hrs for the long pieces) but does not pose difficulties, if you use PLA.
To make it more mechanically robust I designed the pieces as hollow tubes and inserted a long and thin wooden stick (8mm diameter). The pieces are fixed to the staff with headless screws (M4). I cut the threads with a thread cutter, but this might not be necessary.
For printig the pieces, I choose a high percentage for fill for the middel and a lower one for the end. However, that did not affect the printing much, because due to the geometry and size the pieces mainly consist of wall layers anyway. The dimensions of the fully assembled stick are: diameter in the middle: 15mm, diameter at the end 30mm, total length: 66cm Advice: I would get the wooden staff first, test print a bit of one of the pieces and check if the staff fits into the hole of the piece.

comments.text: The idea of an assembled devil stick (but still robust) is interesting :)

title: Filament Spool Wall Holder / Headphone Hanger UPDATED 2015-07-23

description.text:
UPDATE 2015-07-23: Now you can vacuum seal your filament AND hang it at the same time. See my vacuum-seal end cap here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:939583

I couldn't find a filament spool wall hanger to my liking, so I made my own. It also works great for headphones and other hangable items.

There are two lengths available: 75mm for most regular depth spools and 105mm for wide spools, such as BuMat brand.

The hanger pole is set at a 2.2 percent incline to keep the spool secure.

The pole's diameter is small enough that you can keep most spool spacers attached when hanging (for example, my Printrbot Simple Metal Spool Spacers shown here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:322923).

Attach with two #12 screws and anchors. The holes are sized for #12 screws and countersunk for #12 screw heads. These here work well from Home Depot: http://thd.co/1TvK3MI

I recommend printing at .2mm layer height with 15 percent or more infill and 4 vertical shell perimeters (for strength). No supports required.

title: 808 Keychain Camera Motorcycle Helmet Mount Case

description.text:
I had a couple old #11 808 keychain cameras laying around and decided to build a simple low profile case that could mount on my helmet. These are not the best camera's but are great if you just want to video document a ride, and they are cheap.

I wanted more recording time so added a compartment to hold a larger 540mAh battery that increases recording time to over 2 hours. I used small M2x6 screws to hold the tops on but you could just as well super glue them.

The design is not at all water proof so riding in the rain is not an option.

I used 'DAP Blue Stik adhesive putty' to secure the camera circuit card inside the case, and to rotate and secure the camera image sensor so it is horizontal when mounted on top or on the side of my helmet.

The unit is attached to my helmet with velcro.

description.text:
this is wired1's excellent build of the ob1.4 with a larger build envelope of about 380x380x380mm. I wanted to use half of the 1m openbeam length for the base. I used the ob1.4 original diameter rods and placement, I just made them longer. I replaced the front y axis gt2 pully with a larger one from sdp-si.com : 6Z51M036DF0605 , so it would clear the openbeam rail.
this pulley has 36 teeth.
I also had to buy more gt2 belt due to the larger build envelope, this is sdp-si.com part number: 6R51MC060 , I had to use 3meters total for x and y axis. using a lazy susan bearing for the filiment feed.
tried a bed made from granite tile 12" x 12", but it cracked at 70deg C.
so I'm now using 0.25" x 15" x 15" t6061 aluminum plate over 0.375" x 15" x 15" plywood connected directly to the standard ob1.4's y-carriage. printing on blue painters tape and if needed hairspray.
the tape is applied directly to the aluminum plate.
using hossman's dial indicator attachment the aluminum plate is level to +-0.010" over it's surface, ie front to back and side to side; it was easily adjusted using the spring setup showed in the pictures. I'm using plastic zip ties to put the electronics and power supply on the ob1.4 frame so it all moves as a unit. I'm using hossman's long lcd cable configuration and I've had no issues. I'm using repetierHost in ubuntu 12.04 linux and really like it.
I'm using slic3r which comes with repetierHost. I was having globing issues on printed parts as seen in the pictures on z height over about 12mm, this turns out to be an issue where repetierHost needed to have the ping-pong communication turned on, DOAH ! I suspect repetierHost was not waiting for the marlin software and just throwing g-code away. The printer is working very well now at 50mm/sec print speeds.
after some more finer calibration I'll try to up that speed to see what margin it has. thanks again to wired1, hossman and nate for all their help.
[email protected]

description.text:
Mount for a Fatshark 600TVL FPV camera on top of a Hovership MHQ2. I wasn't able to find a good camera mount for the MHQ2 so made this one to fit. Take advantage of the threaded lens and ring to secure the camera onto the mount, then use the existing front screws for the spacers to secure it on. Additional screws on the rear are also possible, the holes are matched.

*Added a 10 deg tilt version for those of you racer types. I added the tilt bottom so the bottom surface is 10 degrees from horizontal. Make sure you tilt the model in your slicing software 10 degrees before you start printing!

Print and mount onto upper clean plate of Hovership MHQ2. Then screw on a fatshark 600 TVL camera and go fly!

Recommend ~30% infill
2-3 outer perimeter

For 10 deg tilt tilt the model 10 degrees in your slicing software before printing so bottom surface is level with bed!

description.text: Here is a fun coaster upon which to place objects of liquid holding.

This is a remix of SubMini - 200mm FPV Quadcopter from user jjmelo. Thanks to him I was able to remix this frame and made some modification to fit my parts.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5wVywlC8SbE

Part's list:

  1. DYS 2300KV 1306 motors
  2. ZTW 12A Opto ESC
  3. CC3D
  4. Lemon DSMX Sat.
  5. Zippy 1000mah 3S 25C, 35C and 40C

If anyone is interested, here are the exact part's list:

1.Motors - http://www.banggood.com/DYS-BX1306-2300KV-Brushless-Motor-3-4S-For-Multicopter-CW-CCW-Set-p-946564.html

2.Flight controller - http://www.banggood.com/New-Version-OpenPilot-CC3D-EVO-Flight-Controller-STM32-32-bit-Flexiport-p-973582.html
New version with satellite port/support

3.Props - http://www.banggood.com/Gemfan-5x3-Inch-Plastic-5030-Propeller-CWCCW-For-240-250-Frame-p-937866.html

4.Battery -http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__72330__ZIPPY_Compact_1000mAh_3s_40c_Lipo_Pack_US_Warehouse_.html

http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__24600__ZIPPY_Compact_1000mAh_3S_25C_Lipo_Pack_USA_Warehouse_.html

5.Lemon RX - http://www.lemon-rx.com/shop/index.php?route=product/product&path=72&product_id=109

6.ESC - http://www.banggood.com/ZTW-Spider-Series-12A-OPTO-ESC-With-SimonK-Program-p-946402.html

7.BEC/Step down converter - http://www.banggood.com/5Pcs-Mini-DC-Adjustable-Power-Supply-Buck-Module-Step-Down-Module-p-952402.html

8.LEDs - Ebay - http://www.ebay.com/itm/381223957510?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

I've tried printing it from 30%-80%, it's up to you. ABS would be ideal but with the thickness and if you use 80% I think it could be a strong frame. ABS was giving me so much trouble that I am currently back to PLA.

You only need 4 3mm screws/hex to mount the CC3D, an XT60 connector and some plastic standoffs (can omit if you don't want legs). With them bolted up the middle is now very strong.

AUW: 188g without battery, 270g with 3S 1000mah 25C lipo. Flight time is about 10-12 minutes.

Leave me a comment/question if you guys need more information.

*** Update (11/29/2015):****
I've crashed and damaged the CC3D and have since replace it with a Naz32 acro. It is still super stable as before but for me it's a lot of fun flying it around compare to the CC3D. I'll upload a video with the Naze32 shortly and can provide my Cleanflight PID if anyone is insterested..

title: Coupler for Living Solutions Personal Blender

description.text: This is a replacement part for the inexpensive Living Solutions Personal Blender sold by Walgreen's. Due to a weakness in the nut trap, the original coupler part in this blender tends to fail when blending frozen foods, ice, or very thick fluids. Compared to the original coupler this part should be more reliable. The outer walls are extra thick for better adhesion between layers, while the nut trap is flanged instead of just having vertical walls prone to weakness at the corners.

I had good success printing this part in white PLA with 40% infill and 0.3mm layers. You should use enough infill for the layers to adhere really well, as this part is under constant stress. The nut trap can be tight, so it may help to heat up the square nut, push it into the trap, and let it cool down before tightening.

This part can be adapted for other blenders by editing the included SCAD file.

I can't take credit for the form factor. Got the idea from the Keyport Keyslide. I liked the idea so i designed a version that can take your keys (up to 3) and i called it the Key Slink. You will have to modify your keys (see picture). Prints without support once oriented correctly.

Cut your keys to 10mm height as in the picture above. Once the case and cover are printed, print the key cap, making 2 extra copies. clip the key into the key cap, ensuring the hole in the key slots around the knob inside the cap (may be a little stiff to get in but that ensures the key doesn't fall out). Once the keys are capped, enter them into the case (there is a stop at the front of the case slots so the keys won't fall out of the front). the back cover will go on very easily so you will need to secure it. If you think you will change the keys in the future, you can use two pieces of thick tape (i used friction tape in the picture above). if you think you want a more 'permanent' solution, you can use epoxy like i did. I can add a keychain loop if you wish so just let me know.

I've got a Panavise model 381. It is a smallish vise, but much bigger and heavier than a third-hand.
I wanted to try to take advantage of this rotating vise head and make a simple modification to allow it to hold a printed circuit board for stability while soldering.
PCBArmAndBase.stl contains a full set of parts. I thought that the depth of the pcb guide slot was too deep.
PCBArmAndBase2.stl also contains a full set of parts. The pcb guide slots were squared off and an angle was applied to the base to give the arms a slight tilt in.

1) Print the Base blocks and arms.
I've used the separate files in the pictures, but there is a file with all four pieces to simplify printing. 2) Disassemble the the vise head and unscrew the existing vise Base blocks. Set them aside for safekeeping. Retain the screws. 3) Screw in the new base blocks. The screw heads are countersunk and the holes should be on the lower side. I made the holes large enough to (hopefully) allow use without drilling, sanding or grinding (all subject to printer settings of course.) 4) Press the key of the arm into the receiver (the L shaped hole) in each base block.

Printed open side down, in PLA, at 220 degrees, with no support. If you don't have a good fan blowing on the piece, you might want to run a minimum-time-per-layer plugin to your software if you had it; otherwise the last layer won't have time to harden before the next is laid upon it.

Print Whale.STL, Lock1.STL, and Lock2.STL with NO SUPPORTS.

Print Splish.STL with FULL SUPPORTS.

Use super glue to glue Lock2 underneath Whale.

You might need to sand or file the bottom of the Splish piece to make it fit in coin slot. You might also need to sand or file the coin slot to make nickels or thicker coins fit.

This is a carriage I've been working on to hold a wades extruder with a Hexagon AO hotend. The spacing of the vertical X axis smooth rod is 45mm from center to center(of rods). I have recently upgraded all the smooth rods on the sE1X to 10mm and have created a 10mm version.

Much like the carriage from the i3 rework, place bearings in, and 2 zip ties per bearing will hold it to the smooth rods. This carriage is mostly designed for Hexagon/ Hexagon AO's which come with a 25mm fan. You will need some m3-10's to mount the fan to the carriage and 4 more if your using the shroud ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922808 ). Enjoy!!

Ever wanted to play chess, checkers, or reversi in the pool? If so, you will love this print! If not, hopefully you'll still love this print! To nutshell, ITS A GOSH DARN FLOATING CHESS/CHECKERS/REVERSI BOARD! YOU CAN PLAY CHESS/CHECKERS/REVERSI ON IT IN THE WATER! It's also my entry into the #MakeItFloat challenge. If you're wondering about the circular slots around the outside, they're the perfect size for holding pennies. If the board tilts one way from the pieces, pennies can be put in the slots to balance it out. It was also part of the challenge, but I decided to make the pennies have an actual purpose, rather than just being cargo! Sorry about how terrible the pictures are, but I can't take a picture of the printed object, because I don't actually have a 3d printer! (Hence my entry into this contest.) Included with my files are chess pieces from the Man Ray Chess Set by SimonParish, (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:388168) because I can't possibly make a more beautiful chess set than that. I also included some generic checkers pieces and reversi pieces. If you would like to print it, you shuld probably take a gander at the instructions. Thanks for looking at my design, hope you like it!

Chess Board:
The chess board is hopefully rather straightforward to make, but heavy on filament. I think it's worth it, but I'm a bit biased. To put the chess set together, you're going to need to print the piece entitled "Chess_Board_Piece" four times, the "Side_Raft" eight times, and the "Square_Construction_Pegs" once. I did warn you that it would be heavy on filament! Once everything has been printed, use the eight shorter construction pegs to connect the four chess board pieces. Two pegs connect two pieces. You can use glue if you like, but make sure that it isn't water-soluble. The circlular slots should be around the outside of the board, as shown in the picture. The next step is to attach the side rafts to the board. Just use the larger construction pegs around the outside of the board, then attach the rafts. Make sure that the opening in the raft is facing downwards. Again, you can use glue to attach the pegs, just make sure it isn't water-soluble. If everything went right, you should now have a floating chess board! While you're playing, the board may tilt a bit one way in the water. If you wish to straighten it, you can place pennies in the circular slots on the side that isn't heavy enough. Enjoy the chess board!

Chess Pieces:
For each set of pieces, you will need to print "Chess_King_And_Queen", "Chess_Knights", "Chess_Bishops", "Chess_Rooks", and "Chess_Pawns" once each. Each set should be a different color, unless you enjoy chaos!

Checkers Pieces:
The checkers pieces are pretty simple to print. Print "Checkers_Pieces" once in one color, and then once in a different color. That's it.

Reversi Pieces:
To print the reversi pieces, print "Reversi_Pieces" four times. Insert witty comment about reversi versus its trademarked counterpart here. :)
Pontoon Boat designed to be a competitor in #MakeItFloat competition, good luck for all :).

My Daughter made the observation that the original Quarter Sub was swimming up and down. With that in mind I have redesigned the Quarter Sub to represent the fish my daughter sees.

Watch the fish dive and breathe......

Print at 100% with PLA or ABS. Or at lesser fill with ABS using a acetone wash to seal the inside chamber. No raft or support is required. Parts are scalable.

Refer to the original Quarter Sub for additional instructions.

One of the projects I was looking to make some head way on during my artist in residency at Maker Media Labs is/was “Weft / Warp.” Last summer I produced a body of work called “Plotting Curves” the majority of which will be exhibited next week at The Compound Gallery in Oakland, CA. These 3D printed pieces are “hand colored” – I shaded in the filament prior to it hitting the hot end with a variety of dye and pigment based marker pens.

I am still impressed that the STL file for the Futaba motor and the Sharpie marker that I pulled off Thingiverse both fit perfectly when I assembled the device this morning. Thank you to txoof and beardicus for sharing the files. I did have to modify the 3d printed part with a soldering iron to move some plastic around on the filament guide and make a hole wider for the motor wire ends.
With “Warp/Weft” i should be able to dial in how much of X and Y is needed to produce A and B. From there i should be able to establish a framework to start thinking about how to make the device more responsive to other inputs and more complicated patterns. There was definitely a fair amount of friction on the filament produced by both the device and the kink going into the top of the machine, this is reflected in a few layers being less the perfect.

I’m honestly not sure that this will work as intended. The “bleed” of the color, and the manner in which the color changes from sharp hues to pastels suggests that getting any kind of detail is going to require a lot of precision, a really big print, or really dense marker pen. Either way i’m excited to have gotten this far. Later on I hope to write more a more complex program that lets the system draw basic shapes and patterns, then images. It would be great to integrate the STL file into this somehow and remove some of the guesswork.
I’m really grateful to Maker Media Lab interns Cameron, Eileen, Adam and Jose for helping me with the project and to Sam Brown for providing the moment of clarity needed to understand what was going wrong and why.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lLH2GXxwnaU

Before printing the whole thing, do a test print to see if it will fit first. I recommend printing it as two piece one at a time rather then printing both at the same time. Use 2 to 10 percent infill with 1 to 3 mm shell. I printed this in 10 percent infill with 1.4 mm shell. Print the infill rate can be increase as much as 50, any more an its just over kill. The shell should be printed with at least 1 mm shell.

I recently add the V2. Print with 10 percent infill with 1.6 shell size. No support required. Like the V1, print one part at a time for best result.

author: javiergavilanes

description.text:
3D printing is being condemned in the media because of the potential for printing guns. We believe there is far more potential for 3D printers to make our lives better rather than killing one another. To encourage thinking about constructive uses of 3D printing technology Michigan Tech Open Sustainability Technology (MOST) Lab and Type A Machines is proud to sponsor the first 3-D Printers for Peace Contest.
Entry Guidelines can be found at: http://www.mtu.edu/materials/printersforpeace/ We are challenging the 3D printing community to design things that advance the cause of peace. Come up with a good design and win a free 3D printer.
Deadline is OVER.
This component is part of an open source lab library, by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group.

The zip files are for the Michigan Tech's MOST version of the RepRap Prusa Mendel open-source 3D printer kit.
The RepRap can be built in a weekend. It has a 7.8 -by-7.8-by-6.8-inch build volume on a heated bed, prints comfortably at 80 mm/sec ABS, 45 mm/sec PLA, HDPE and PVA with 0.1 mm resolution. Assembly instructions with images on Appropedia Thanks to Jerry for the designs. For some ideas on ways 3D printers could be used for sustainable development see this
or consider more complicated devices that use 3D printing as a major component such as this [open-source colorimeter]( http://www.academia.edu/3333921/Open-Source_Colorimeter)

I got to thinking around what products we can replace for a more suitable material to reduce planet resources and environmental impact that comes along with the use of that resource. This competition is not the 'be all and end all' for what we can imagine, design...and intimately achieve tangible goals with. It really is up to us!...............Good luck everyone. Hope to hear from you soon.

title: [v2.0] Prusa i3 X-axis lead screw upgrade

description.text:
Currently working on next stage of our printer's "evolution." Moving the leadscrew upgrade off the original Prusa frame and onto a more sturdy and spacious 15mm aluminum extrusion frame, 600mm³, fully enclosed with doors

We begin this Thing post with a working X-Carriage:

  • Compatible with our previous Prusa-frame based X-axis lead screw upgrade design published here.
  • Designed with a common 24mm CL-to-CL hole spacing for hot-end mount
  • Two mount points available for mount height versatility.

Look forward to updates!

Print with infill [>50%]
Optimized layer height [.2mm]

ABS Recommended

Align and zip-tie the linear bearings/bushings

comments.text: Impressive upgrade.  I wouldn't mind trying this.  How did you determine that you need 8mm pitch 2mm lead for your X/Y axis lead screws?  I have read that this is a big consideration based on your motor.   Are the 8mm screws compatible with all Prusa style motors?

comments.text: No change in smooth rod spacing. In both carriages, smooth rod center-to-center distance is 52mm. The upgraded X-carriage drops right into the original lead-screw X-axis upgrade we posted.

title: Pomodoro tech---An arduino based desktop pomodoro timing skill.

description.text:
The Pomodoro Technique is a time management method developed by Francesco Cirillo in the late 1980s. The technique uses a timer to break down work into intervals traditionally 25 minutes in length, separated by short breaks. These intervals are known as "pomodori", the plural of the Italian word pomodoro for "tomato". The method is based on the idea that frequent breaks can improve mental agility. ----copy from wikipedia.

As a maker, I'm really look high to the working productivity. Since that, I've been trying to use some time management app on my iphone. But after a period using I find out that the phone was just maked me distract all the time. I have been spent a large amount of time when facebook or twitter notification comes up which I don't even notice. Finally, I‘ve decided to pick up my seeeduino and work out these little cut gadget which keep me focus on work.

remixed_from.author: gwpoulos
remixed_from.title: Customizable Parametric Handle with Grip and Guard

description.text:
Create a handle from one of several (15) profiles generated in Inkscape.
Add grips, a ferrule, holes for hanging, or grub-screwing to a tool.
Also flat faces for hand carving.
Scale or shift the profiles.
Or make new profiles in Inkscape and manually add to the program. (Instructions in the code).

Dowload or use the Customizer. Several tabs for overall shape and grips etc.

How to make/load in profiles from Inkscape:
Sample svg included in files.
In Inkscape:

  1. Set document properties to mm and set size to 100mm high x 50mm wide.
  2. Draw right hand side of profile shape. Neck end pointing down.
  3. Make sure first point is at top.
  4. Last point of profile must be directly below the first. Closed or open profile - does not matter.
  5. Exact placement and scale on sheet is not important. (calculated from data)
  6. Export profile using "Paths to OpenSCAD" Extension
    -see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036

In the SCAD file:

  1. Open the .scad file and clip out the [[],[],...] region inside polygon() definition.
  2. Paste that list into a new variable(unique name) in the SCAD filet similar to ones included.
  3. Add that variable to the "profiles" list variable (below the list of profiles).
  4. Add the name of the profile to the "Profile_shape" param for the Customiser near start of file.

description.text:

Case designed by makercase.com, modified in Corel Draw X6.

Prototype made from 3mm MDF, with 3mm dowel hinge pins.
Cut it from 3mm material, put it together. Note that the front and back are different. Push the dowel into the hinge holes, then rotate it against a blade to cut it, and add a dab of glue.

Since it was not easy for a pal of mine to find a bleed block for the Formula RX disk brakes here in Germany, I designed and printed one myself. The bleed block is necessary when you bleed your brakes to hold the brake pistons in place, so that they don't get pushed out of the brake body.

The gallery shows the V1 version that fits quite nicely into the brake block. Version V2 has a little wider hole for the fixation screw to fit more easily as well as it is rounder on the bottom to match the brake body shape - an aesthetic thing...

Print it with three to four top / bottom layers and an infill of above 10% to withstand the pressure forces of the brake's pistons. When using a honeycomb or rectangular infill pattern it is not necessary to have a too dense infill. I've printed the bleed block with PLA.

Please report any issues in dimensions and shape so I can optimize the bleed block further.

• 3 to 4 top and bottom layers
  • 10% or more infill to withstand brake pressure
  • honeycomb or rectangular infill pattern preferably

then bob may be your uncle.

I'm working on an openscad script to generate cuts for a sliceform of a openscad form.  This takes advantage of the new 2d features of openscad and the dxf export.  I have had issues with the dxf export and compatability, this have been fixed in the latest development snapshot, so that is what I am using now.
This project was inspired by the RACKO thing by JSP7707.

Run the openscad script, and export the results as a dxf file. YOu may want to adjust the layout of the file before cutting. The script lays out two rows of shapes, one row for each slice orientation. The parts are in placed in order. If you don't want to use openscad, (I recommend using the current dev snapshot for this script), I also included the dxf file for the sphere in the picture. It is made from Office Depot neon poster board, which is about .3mm thick. The thickness in the openscad accounts for the laser cutter
s kerf of about .1mm. The form that is sliced is defined in form(). Right now it is a sphere. I expected the output to be symmetric, but it isn't. I'm wondering if the openscad sphere primitive isn't perfectly asymmetrical. Now that the sphere is working, I will probably try a more complex form. The script assumes that the form is centered on the origin. The meeting point for the cuts will be on the x=0 or y=0 plane. I would like to find a way to label the slices to make keeping them in order easier, but there is no 2d text primitive in openscad, and there is no way to put something on another layer of the outputed dxf.

Spent 2 or 3 hours designing this wonderful thing. It's a fully functional 1u rack case, featuring space for a motherboard, power supply, SSD, and even a PCI card!

Things to keep in mind:

-The hole for the motherboard IO is not intended to fit a backplane.
-The hole for the PCI slot is designed to be used with a flexible PCIe extender. It probably won't work with a rigid one!

I've done a test print, in 6 pieces, and I fixed the problems I found. So it should work perfectly now, but no guarantees.
Cut it into as many pieces as required to fit your 3D printer. Print it off, and melt it together with Acetone, or hot glue it.

  • 1pcs M3 scew 6mm long.

author: chaueq

description.text:
These objects were designed for the Thingiversity Science Challenge: Make It Float. The challenge consists of the creation of a 3D model of a boat or other floating object. To increase your chances of winning, 3D print your model and then test, redesign, and retest to optimize the amount of weight your boat can support using coins in your local currency, and this is our story:

The best an optimum solution for this contest is a box, with dimensions a multiple of the coin diameter, and as high as your printer limits. But a box is hard to push through the water...

But we wanted to reproduce a real ship for this contest, so we choose a catamaran (double hull ship) that could take the coins with style... and certain speed. The real ship is named Zephyr and is a wind turbine service catamaran, that is able to run at 26 knots.
A catamaran hull presents better speed and stability for carrying load (including coins). See our video of the prototype advancing in the water with a slightly touch.

We starded designing from the scratch, using Rhinoceros for modeling the hull, based on pictures and technical drawings from magazines (see pictures). This took a veeeeery long time.
We also played some CFD (computer fluyd dynamics) in order to check how the ship will behave in reality at 26 knots. (See the coloured pictures that show the wave pattern of the ship). From these calculations you can obtain the size of the motor that you are going to install to get the speed. We obtained a good aproach with the real power onboard according the magazines. That means that our design was similar to the one of the real ship.

Regarding printing, we started with a one piece prototype with the horizontal deck paralell to the printer base, Cat_Zephyr_1.stl. We had problems printing such a large plane deck that made the ship a non-watertight ship (bad idea for a ship), so we produced a slightly smaller hull, printed in vertical, Cat_Zephyr_2.stl. That presented a better finnishing but it was too heavy to carry (with or without style) some 5 cents euro coins.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IK4HD882nTA

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-I7eEMudPU8

Based on these two previous prototypes, for the final solution we have constructed a two pieced hull, hollow in its side hulls so coins can fit inside. The model is about 28 cm length (the key is that the weight is scaled with the 3rd power of the scale, so if you construct a ship that has double dimmensions, you will have eight time more volume that the previous design.

Our final design weigths 198 gr, and is able to carry a load of 5 cents euro coins of 723 gr before sinking. It can advance well in water with a weight of 803 gr (with 605 gr of coins inside).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xl3zDsv7pgs

Thank you to the people of the model basin of the Technical University of Madrid (CEHINAV). The water basins and electronic weight are from this laboratory.

Software: Repetier with slic3r.

zephyr1.stl and zephyr2.stl:
can be made at 0.2 mm, even 0.1 mm, 3 shells, Infill 15%, speed about 40 mm/s

zephyr3.stl:
The bigger version needs more than 8 hours with 0.2 mm, so we used 0.3 mm, 2 shells, infill 10 %, speed about 44 mm/s.

No support surfaces are needed for the three prototypes.
Printed in ABS on 0,2 layer height in black for Flashforge Creator Dual
DC Logo - Print it with a little support
Print with support under the flap - i left a small gap to remove. It prints really well.

comments.text: You'll see on my own post I was pretty happy with this. Was just wondering if maybe the "C" part could be made a little thicker? Could do with being just a little bit sturdier. Otherwise real good design, cheers!

title: Connector for 5mm x 5mm wooden struts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Customizable connector with optional print support

Use the customizer to create your own connectors.
This version only supports 5mm x 5mm struts with 90° angles.

Set all needed directions in the "directions" parameter string.

  • n = north
  • e = east
  • s = south
  • w = west
  • u = up
  • d = down

If your 3d printer doesn't print bridges properly, you can activate the support feature by using the upper case character for your directions.

So NSEWud prints the connectors for "north", "south", "east" and "west" with support and "up" and "down" without

description.text:
This is a simple 3D printed RC boat, optimized for 0.4mm nozzles.

The entire build can be done in only 3 hours (including print time)!

The boat uses very simple and common electronics:

  • any transmitter and reciever
  • small standard brushed motor (see pictures)
  • small servo like this one: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__9392__Turnigy_MG90S_Digital_Metal_Gear_Servo_1_8kg_13_4g_0_10sec.html
  • an ESC made out of an old servo controller (http://www.instructables.com/id/Jury-Rigging-A-Servo-To-Drive-A-Low-Voltage-Motor/#step1)

To make the boat water tight, several layers of ABS slurry were applyed on the inside and outside (http://www.instructables.com/id/100-Warp-Free-MakerBot-3D-Printing/step1/Put-ABS-Scraps-and-Acetone-in-a-Jar/)

I hope you enjoy this little project, and be sure to check out my profile for more RC stuff!

Printed at 0.2mm layer and 60mm/sec in about 2 to 3 hours.

Only the boat part needs a little support in the middle and in the back.
(See photos for print orientation)

description.text:
When calamity strikes and desperation sets in it's time to kludge. My MK6 hotend and I had developed a very destructive relationship, and this time I was sure she was never coming back. But when your friend needs a shiny new Mendel one must work with what one's got. In this case, one had a piece of 1/4 inch aluminum and nichrome wire. This hotend is about as unsafe as you can get, do not use it unless you keep the entire bucket brigade on retainer. Perks to this nozzle include:
  • Heat-up time of 20s
  • Glowing metal
  • Increased alertness via fear of death
    • If you are desperate enough to repeat this folly, please tell us. Or at least your wife, girlfriend, friends, neighbors...maybe update your will.
    I see we already have one thing tagged kludge...well here's another.

• Tap your aluminum bar to 3/8 - 24 and drill holes for mounting screws
  • Thread nozzle halfway through
  • Thread insulator tube to other side
  • Wrap Kapton tape around remaining threads of nozzle
  • Wrap 200mm (4-6 ohms) nichrome around kapton'd thread of nozzle
  • Find precarious place for thermocouple and haphazardly secure
  • DOUBLE CHECK your thermocouple is secure
  • Solder nichrome wire to heating wire
  • Carelessly bolt hotend to attachment plate
  • Pray

description.text:
Allows you to use different tubes with these mini grease guns.
Currently set to toothpaste tubes.

Toothpaste is an abrasive substance
which is the last thing you want where grease is supposed to go.

Make sure the tube is clean. Then clean it again. and then clean it some more

Use the plunger to fill empty tubes with grease.

1.Filling the tube
Partially fill a tube with grease, then swing the grease to the bottom of the tube. Push the air out and continue filling the remainder of the tube.

2.Fitting the tube
Loosely screw the tube to the gun. Squeeze until grease comes out the side and then fully tighten.

description.text:
After a brief and well, fiery romance with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9234 I said my goodbyes, bit the bullet and looked at my old MK6. "Hello MK6 hotend." I said
"I hate you." Came the reply
"I wanted to love you, but you came apart at the seems."
"As if you would know, when was the last time you touched me." She countered
"I could see it, your resistors cracking and going to bits."
(Tearful dialogue continues, segway into abrupt technical jabble) This is a rework of the stock MK6 that embeds the power resistors in the steel in an MK6 PLUS-esque fashion. It heats up quickly and gives a bit more room for a cooling fan. It has printed spectacularly for 12 hours, but I cannot speak for the long term success so keep that in mind, should anything happen as I continue printing that would be pertinent I will update. This is an all or nothing process that cannot be undone. Once you start, you must finish or have a backup plan ie. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8094 .

Completely disassemble your hotend Power Resistor Prep:
  • Gently and firmly so as not to break your resistor leads, tap/wiggle your resistors out of their chassis
  • Crack off the insulation surrounding them
  • Use a ohm-meter to confirm they still read 5 ohms
  • Measure the maximum diameter, mine was .2". Your's is probably the same but be certain
    • Heating Block:
    Using a 7/32" (1/4" if daring) drill through your heating block as shown in the picture, taking care to avoid choosing a spot that drills through your thermocouple mount screw. I used a drill press and bought a nice fancy bit specifically for this task, you can skimp on these but I wouldn't recommend it. I'm not familiar enough with drilling this kind of material to give some good tips on method so if you've only drilled wood, do some research on cutting a big thick hole through stainless steel. Put it all together:
  • Wrap your resistors in kapton tape to insulate them and beef up their diameter so they fit snugly in their newly drilled home.
  • Use that ohm-meter again to check the your resistors are electrically isolated from both each other and the heating block. Check it twice.
  • Kapton a bit around the heating block where your resistors poke out if your nervous like me and don't entirely trust the solder your using from deciding it should goop about a bit while printing.
  • Using solder with a melting point higher than your operating temperature, solder your resistors as in the MK6 assembly instructions.
  • Reassemble your heating block
  • Carefully monitor your new hotend during its first few prints JUST to be sure your house won't go down in a fiery blaze.
  • You're done, AND awesome. How cool is that, huh?

comments.text: Now, why would you want to do this? Just to get faster heat-up time?
comments.author: pauldebra

comments.text: Hey, if your hotend is working great, don't change what ain't broke. Mine broke. To be honest, i've never been a fan of strapping those resistors to the side of the block. They're further away from the thermocouple and filament, are of a different material than the block, awkward to insulate and aim over 75% of their heat dissipation away from the core. As such it seemed they were pulling much more power than needed and had a large lag time making my PID hard to tune and keep stable. This is all compounded by the fact I need to run my machine in a post building shop that is basically ambient and has huge 12ft high double doors open most of the day during more than moderate winds, not ideal. I'm not going to speak for the math, but I can say my bot is operating much smoother, drawing less power, heating up faster, is more temperature stable and the filament temperature seems to more closely match the reported temperature. In the beginning it was an act of necessity as my resistors were cracked and powdering out, but after the fact I can say its running better than ever.
comments.author: pauldebra

comments.text: I don't think you want your resistors insulated, but rather you want high thermal conductivity. I wrap mine in tine foil being careful not to ground out the wires.
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: You want the wire coil electrically insulated, mine weren't after I removed them from their casing. The Kapton insulates them electrically. I almost made the hole 1/4" to accommodate furnace cement but wasn't certain I had the clearance or steady enough hand to not drill through the side of the block. I can say most certainly you should NOT wrap these in tin foil as they are bare metal in spots and will short to themselves and the heating block.
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: I didn't realize the coil was exposed. You could also try painting it with silicone barbeque paint, then wrap it in something with better thermal conductivity.
comments.author: LukeChilson

comments.text: oooh, thats an idea. I may check that item out as a high temperature insulator.
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

Holds 4 reels per panel. The prongs are tilted to 15Âº. If you need more than four reels, print duplicates and tessellate.  
Sized at 120mm per side. Fits nicely on a Replicator 1. Printing the first one now at 50% infill (overkill, but the prongs are in the wrong orientation to get much strength without the extra plastic). No signs of lifting so far.

This is an upgrade to the printable microscope (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:77450) that helps you to use your smartphone to easily take digital photos with this microscope. You can see some of the photos I have taken of varius microstructures around the house. I tried to design this to work with a variety of phones but have only tested it with an iPhone 4S, so I am looking for feedback on how to better generalize this if necessary.

You should be able to print this with a variety of printers and settings. I built it using a MakerBot Replicator 2 on the MakerWare medium settings and 0.27mm layer thickness. For the two clamps, I printed with a higher infill (30%) for strength and 15% for the body.

comments.text: Idea for your next 3D printed microscope:
comments.author: pyrophreek

title: Actobotics Motor To RC Wheel Adapter

description.text: I made this adapter to allow me to attach 1/10 touring car wheels with 12mm hex hubs to the gearmotor output shafts on my actobotics right-angle plastic gearmotors. I use these for my antweight (1 lb) battlebot :-)
I printed these at .25 layer height, 40% infill, with three shells, in HIPS plastic. I then brushed the outside with weld-on #4 using a q-tip to improve layer adhesion for extra strength.
